head.title: Finding a Secret Weapon In the Old Queen's Gambit

identified-content.classifier: Politiken Cup International Open Chess Tournament

hedline.hl1: Finding a Secret Weapon In the Old Queen's Gambit

abstract.p: Robert Byrne chess column reports there are three winners of Politiken Cup International Open Chess Tournament: Boris Gulko, Lars Bo Hansen and Jonny Hector; diagram (M)

block.p: The traditional Politiken Cup International Open Tournament in Copenhagen, July 17-28, was won jointly by Boris Gulko of Fairlawn, N.J., Lars Bo Hansen of Denmark and Jonny Hector of Sweden.

The three grandmasters each scored 8 1/2 points in the 11-round, 165-entrant competition. The American grandmaster Nick DeFirmian, who lives in Copenhagen, scored 8 points for a seven-way tie for 4th to 10th places.
The traditional Politiken Cup International Open Tournament in Copenhagen, July 17-28, was won jointly by Boris Gulko of Fairlawn, N.J., Lars Bo Hansen of Denmark and Jonny Hector of Sweden.

The three grandmasters each scored 8 1/2 points in the 11-round, 165-entrant competition. The American grandmaster Nick DeFirmian, who lives in Copenhagen, scored 8 points for a seven-way tie for 4th to 10th places.

Gulko, who enjoys the distinction of being a former champion of both the U.S.S.R. and the United States, was in good form in his Round 3 game with the international master Bjorn Brinck Claussen of Denmark. He picked one of the most tortuous openings in chess and wove his way through it with great style.

Developing the white queen bishop with 5 Bg5 introduces the Anti-Meran Gambit in the Semi-Slav Defense. This aggressively bypasses the Meran Variation, which arises after 5 e3 Nbd7 6 Bd3 dc 7 Bc4 b5 Bd3 a6. White is first to sacrifice a pawn, but who is really giving up material remains unclear until after manifold skirmishing.

After 9 Ng5, the major alternative to 9 . . . hg is 9 . . . Nd5, but in a game in Merida, Mexico, last year, Gulko crushed Reynaldo Vera with 10 Nf7 Qh4 11 Nh8 Bb4 12 Rc1 c5 13 dc Nd7 14 Be2 Ne5 15 O-O Bb7 16 Nb5 Rd8 17 Qa4 Nf4 18 Nd4 Kf8 19 Ne6! Ne6 20 Qb4 Bc6 21 f4 Kg8 22 Qe1 Qe1 23 Rce1 Resigns.

Black's strategy became visible after 12 . . . c5. White cannot play 13 dc?! because Black would mobilize powerfully with 13 . . . Nc5 followed by 14 . . . Bb7 and 15 . . . Rd8. However, White has at his disposal the combative thrust 13 d5.
Currently, sacrificing a piece with 16 Rb1! is the favored strategem. After 16 . . . Bh6 17 Bh6 Rh6, White's 18 b3! opens terrain for an attack on the enemy king.

Through 21 . . . Qb2, the players were following a Khalifman-Galkin game in Elista 1998, but even though White won that one, beginning with 22 e7, Gulko displayed confidence in proceeding with 22 ed7!? He was now revising a Novikov-Ivanov game in St. Petersburg 1996, which went 22 . . . Rd7, but instead of 23 Qf3, which led to a draw after c2 24 Qc6 Kd8 25 Qa8 Kc7 26 Qc6, he produced his secret weapon: 23 Qg4!
After 27 Bd7 Kd7, Gulko had recovered his material and the black king was exposed, whereas the white king was safe. Brinck Claussen's threat was his far-advanced passed c pawn.
After 28 Re1, Brinck Claussen could not advance 28 . . . c2 because of 29 Qe8 Kc7 30 Re7 Kb6 31 Qb8. After 28 . . . Re6 29 Rd1 Rd6 30 Qf5 Ke7 31 Qe5 Re6 32 Qg5 f6 33 Qg7 Ke8, 34 Qd7 wins.
After 39 Rb1, there was no way to stop 40 Qb7mate or 40 Qb5mate other than to sacrifice the queen with 39 . . . Qb1 40 Qb1.
After 42 Qd4, there could have come 42 . . . Kb4 43 Qb2 Ka5 44 Qc3, and the black pawns are going nowhere. Brinck Claussen gave up.
